newsitem.title: KENYA: Iran president says U.S. wrong in Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Iran president says U.S. wrong in Iraq.

text.p: Iranian President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani criticised the United States on Wednesday for its cruise missile attacks against Iraq but said the Iraqis had provided the pretext.
"The Americans are moving wrong in Iraq and the Iraqis have given them the pretext," Rafsanjani, speaking through an interpreter, told Reuters on the third day of a state visit to Kenya.
Rafsanjani called events in Iraq, Iran's western neighbour and a longstanding enemy, "very bad incidents".
Asked whether there was anything he could do to avert further violence, the Iranian leader said: "We are trying, but it is very difficult."
The U.S. fired cruise missiles at Iraqi air defence targets on Tuesday and Wednesday in retaliation for Saturday's incursion by Iraqi armed forces into Kurdish areas in northern Iraq.
Rafsanjani was speaking during a tour of an agricultural research station at Muguga, 40 km (25 miles) north of Nairobi.
After leaving Kenya on Thursday, Rafsanjani is due to visit Uganda, South Africa, Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Sudan.
Western diplomats say the Iranian president is hoping to strengthen ties in Africa as part of Tehran's campaign to lessen its international isolation and the impact of U.S. sanctions.
Washington accuses Iran of sponsoring terrorism, a charge Iran denies.
On Tuesday Rafsanjani offered the hand of brotherhood to Africa instead of what he termed the raping of the continent by colonialists.

Speaking at Moslem prayers in the Indian Ocean port of Mombasa, a gateway to much of East and central Africa, Rafsanjani said Western powers had "raped the land in the name of civilisation" when they colonised Africa.
At a dinner hosted by Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi on Monday, Rafsanjani urged Kenya to support a drive for the "democratic restructuring" of the United Nations.
"The rich countries are using the United Nations as an instrument to pursue their own political objectives," he said.
